However, the open economy approach is very important for some countries, such as the UK. â€¢ We are going to focus on one aspect of open economy macroeconomics: exchange rate fluctuations. â€¢ Since the collapse of the Bretton Woods system in 1973, most countries allowed their exchange rates to float. Learning Objectives Under this topic, we will learn about: â€¢ Exchange rate swings â€¢ The Dornbusch (Exchange rate overshooting) model â€¢ The effect of an increase in the money supply in the Dornbusch model â€¢ Implications of the Dornbusch model Exchange Rate Swings 130 135 140 145 150 155 160 165 170 Nominal Effective Exchange Rate of Â£ (Source: IMF International Financial Statistics) â€¢ The era of flexible exchange rates has been characterised by major exchange rate swings. â€¢ An exchange rate swing refers to a change in the exchange rate by 20% or more over a period of 1-2 years. Exchange Rate Swings â€¢ Economists wanted to find out whether these big swings â€¢ were due to â€œirrationalâ€ speculative behaviour by exchange rate traders or â€¢ whether they could be explained by systematic macroeconomic forces in which expectations remained â€œrationalâ€ â€¢ This question surfaced in the 1970s as the idea of â€œrational expectationsâ€ was being introduced into macroeconomics by the New Classical School then, as we have seen. â€¢ An answer to this question was proposed by Rudiger Dornbusch. â€¢ Remark: the well-known Mundell-Fleming open-economy macro model not only takes no account of expectations, but it also assumes a fixed price level, which limits its relevance to only short horizons. The Dornbusch Model â€¢ Dornbusch suggested that big exchange rate swings can be consistent with rational expectations. â€¢ His analysis became to be known as the exchange rate overshooting model. â€¢ The model is eclectic, since it combines the New Classical assumption of rational expectations with the New Keynesian assumption of sticky prices. â€¢ It is, however, not New Keynesian as it does not provide micro foundations for the structural macroeconomic relationships. Source: Dornbusch RÃ¼diger (1942-2002) â€“ The Ideas of Economists The Dornbusch Model â€¢ The originality of Dornbusch's work lies in his exploration of the outcome of an important observation. â€¢ While product markets adjust only slowly, financial markets appear to adjust far more rapidly. â€¢ The consequence of allowing for this feature of the real world turns out to be that financial markets have to over adjust to disturbances, in order to compensate for the stickiness of prices in goods markets. Implication of the Dornbusch model â€¢ The model demonstrates how we can have large exchange rate swings, even with rational expectations. â€¢ Hence, large exchange rate swings are not necessarily a sign of traders in the forex market having irrational expectations about the future of exchange rates. â€¢ Their expectations are linked to fundamentals of the economy. Intuitive Explanation of Overshooting â€¢ The increased money supply leads to excess supply in the money market. Prices are sticky so the real interest rate must fall to restore equilibrium: ğ’ğ’ âˆ’ ğ’‘ğ’‘ = ğ’Œğ’Œ Ì„ğ’šğ’š âˆ’ ğ’ğ’ğ’“ğ’“ â€¢ The decrease in the domestic real interest rate results in a negative interest rate differential. Hence, Ì‡ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘’ must become negative to maintain the UIP condition: ğ’“ğ’“ = ğ’“ğ’“âˆ— + Ì‡ğ’”ğ’”ğ’†ğ’† â€¢ In other words, investors expect the home currency to appreciate. â€¢ In the long-run, we know s will be higher (i.e. depreciate) in proportion to the rise in m. â€¢ The only way for s to be higher in the long-run but be falling (as correctly expected) along the transition path is for s to jump beyond the new long-run value, i.e. initially depreciate more. Comments on the overshooting â€¢ The â€œintuitiveâ€ explanation shows that rational expectations play a key role in causing overshooting, as the logic of why the exchange rate overshoots would break down if we donâ€™t have Ì‡ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘’ = Ì‡ğ‘ ğ‘ . â€¢ This explanation also shows that sticky prices play a key role in causing overshooting, as ğ‘ğ‘ would immediately increase in proportion to ğ‘šğ‘š if prices were flexible and ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ would not decrease. â€¢ Ì‡ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘’ would then remain constant and ğ‘ ğ‘  would immediately jump to its higher long-run value without overshooting. Comments on the overshooting â€¢ Notice that since ğ‘ğ‘ does not change on impact, the real exchange rate (ğ‘ ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘ğ‘) also depreciates on impact. â€¢ Through the IS (ğ‘¦ğ‘¦ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ = â„(ğ‘ ğ‘  âˆ’ ğ‘ğ‘)), we know that the depreciation of the real exchange rate results in an increase in real output, i.e. causes a boom if we assume ğ‘¦ğ‘¦ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ = ğ‘¦ğ‘¦. â€¢ In this case, the overshooting of the exchange rate can be thought to result in a boom in the short-run by departing real output from its long-run level. â€¢ However, recall that Dornbusch assumes ğ‘¦ğ‘¦ = Ì„ğ‘¦ğ‘¦, in which case real output does not change. Comments on the overshooting â€¢ In our analysis here, we assumed that the change in the money supply by policy-makers was unexpected. â€¢ In an important extension of the Dornbusch model where the money supply change is anticipated, it has been shown that the overshooting in this case would be lower. â€¢ Intuitively, the reason is that, from the moment the markets become aware that the money supply is going to increase, they would change their judgement about the long-run equilibrium. â€¢ The result is then for the whole process of adjustment to start immediately, thereby smoothing somewhat the impact of the money supply increase, when it actually takes place. â€¢ It is important to note that this approach assumes that the market is correct in anticipating a money supply increase. â€¢ In practice, the markets may often anticipate monetary policy changes that fail to materialize, causing exchange rate movements that cannot be rationalized.
